text:
Corporation for Public Broadcasting
555 Madison Avenue
New York, N. Y. 10022
(212) 582-
April 18, 1969
Mr. Steven A. Bookshester
United States National
Student Association
2115 S. Street, N.W.
Washington, D. C. 20008
Dear-Mr. Bookshester:
This letter is in response to your proposal for a
New Program of Radio Production to Serve Needs in Higher
Education and Community Development dated February 24, 1969.
I regret that we are not able to fund this proposal. >
There are many good ideas in the proposal that you have
developed and you are to be commended for the effort,
which you have made in thinking through some of these
problems and for your concern for the subject matter and
the audience you intend to reach. We are not, however,
prepared to move ahead on the recommendations you have
made to us. _
We would encourage the National Student Association to
pursue some . off the possibilities outlined in your
proposal and would suggest that you discuss this matter
with Mr. Robert Mott, Executive Director of National
Educational Radio. Mr. Mott's office is located at
1346 Connecticut Ave. N.W. in Washington D. C.
and you can reach him at 667-6000. Mr. Mott is directly
responsible for the operation of the National Educational
Radio Network and working through his organization would
be the most effective means of distributing programming to
public radio stations today. I'm sure Mr. Mott will be
happy to discuss these matters with you and explore the
possibilities that might exist for implementation for
some of the ideas you suggest.
Sincerely yours,
Donald R. Quayle
Director of Network Affairs
DRQ/jms
